exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The grey light before dawn seeps through the shuttered windows as the servant leads you through the quiet corridors of the palazzo. Your footsteps echo against marble floors that have heard the tread of cardinals, ambassadors, and conspirators for generations. Rome sleeps, but you carry documents that will wake her with a thunderclap.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The door to Lucia's chamber stands slightly ajar. A single candle burns within—she has been waiting. You push the door open. Lucia sits in a high-backed chair near the window, wrapped in a fur-lined robe against the March chill. Her dark hair falls loose around her shoulders—she has not slept. Her grey-green eyes, sharp as ever, track you as you enter. On the table beside her, an untouched cup of wine has grown a skin of dust.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She takes in your appearance in one long, measured look: the ink stains on your fingers, the rumpled clothing, the particular quality of exhaustion that comes from something beyond mere physical labor. She does not rise. Does not rush to embrace you. Does not speak. Instead, she tilts her head slightly—that gesture you have come to know well. The one that says: I have been sitting here for hours imagining you dead in a Vatican cellar, and you will explain yourself thoroughly before I decide whether to be relieved or furious.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You smell of incense and old books. And something else. Fear, perhaps. Though not your own. Whose fear have you been breathing, marito mio?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Your sense of smell is impeccable love. I have been hammering away. And with result. Tomorrow, the pope will declare a reform that will shake the foundations of the church. Remember today and tomorrow love.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The kiss lands on lips that remain still for a moment—not cold, but evaluating. Then she softens, just slightly, and her hand comes up to rest against your chest. She can feel your heartbeat, still quick from the night's work. When you pull back, her expression has shifted. The sharp edge remains, but curiosity has joined it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Shake the foundations. You have been with Eugenius all night. Drafting something. The Camera reform you spoke of. You actually convinced him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns back to you. She crosses her arms beneath her robe, studying you with that penetrating gaze that misses nothing.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: And Parentucelli? The scholar Eugenius summoned? He is involved?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves closer, and now you can see the shadows under her eyes, the tension in her shoulders from a night of waiting and imagining the worst.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tell me what you have done, Juan. Not poetry—specifics. Because if the Pope announces reform that shakes foundations, there will be men in this city who would rather see those foundations buried atop anyone who threatens them. And I have been sitting here in the dark while my husband walked into that nest of vipers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She waits, one hand unconsciously moving to rest on her belly where your child grows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I take her to bed and tell her everything of what happened.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Lucia's chamber at dawn after spending the night drafting church reform documents with Pope Eugenius. Lucia, who has waited anxiously through the night while pregnant, confronts him about the dangers he has exposed himself to. Juan decides to share the full details of what transpired during the night-long session with the Pope and Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: And Parentucelli? The scholar Eugenius summoned? He is involved?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves closer, and now you can see the shadows under her eyes, the tension in her shoulders from a night of waiting and imagining the worst.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tell me what you have done, Juan. Not poetry—specifics. Because if the Pope announces reform that shakes foundations, there will be men in this city who would rather see those foundations buried atop anyone who threatens them. And I have been sitting here in the dark while my husband walked into that nest of vipers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She waits, one hand unconsciously moving to rest on her belly where your second child grows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I take her to bed and tell her everything of what happened.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bed is still warm from where she had lain earlier, trying and failing to sleep. You settle against the pillows together, her body curling against yours despite the residual tension in her frame. The candle gutters low. Through the cracked shutter, Rome's rooftops catch the first grey hints of dawn. You tell her everything. The audience. Eugenius's initial guardedness, then the moment something cracked open when you spoke of faith—real faith, not political faith. The Pope's confession that he had lost belief in his own Church. The fear in his eyes when he spoke of the Camera, the corrupt cardinals, the Basel faction watching his every move. You tell her about the crusade treasury—how it may already be gone, consumed by the structural deficit that devours everything Rome touches. You tell her about the clean slate. The elegant trap: nullify all existing arrangements, transfer the obligations to the College of Cardinals, let the corrupt men fight among themselves over scraps while a reformed Camera rises lean and honest. You tell her about the scholar summoned in the middle of the night—Tommaso Parentucelli, a man with ink-stained fingers and twenty years of quiet fury at what he had witnessed. A man who knew everything about how the corruption worked because he had watched it happen, powerless, for two decades. You tell her about the documents signed before dawn. The Extraordinary Commission. The Motu Proprio declaration. The Bull of Reform with its twenty articles. You tell her about the plan for tomorrow—today, now—the Mass at St. Peter's, the public announcement, Parentucelli securing the Camera building with Castilian knights before the corrupt officials can burn their records or flee with what remains of the treasury.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When you finish, the candle has burned to a stub. Pale light fills the room. Lucia is silent for a long moment. Her hand has found yours, gripping it tightly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tommaso Parentucelli. A secretary. No family, no income, no protection. And you have made him the most dangerous man in Rome. He will need guards. Not just for today—for months. Years, perhaps. The men whose arrangements he will unravel... they will not simply accept this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She shifts, propping herself up on one elbow to look at you directly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The cardinals. Colonna, Orsini, the French faction. They will know by noon that their world is ending. What stops them from... You said Castilian knights will secure the Camera. How many? And what of us? What of this palazzo? What of Catalina, sleeping down the hall?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I wanted to move you, Catalina and the rest of the court back to the ships. If there is trouble, you can just sail away to Naples. You will be secure there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's expression flickers—something passes behind her eyes too quickly to name. She pulls back slightly, sitting up against the headboard.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: To the ships. While you remain here.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She looks toward the window where dawn is strengthening, painting the walls in shades of rose and gold. When she speaks again, her tone has an edge to it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I remember a garden in Toledo. A man kneeling before me with a ring. He said I would stand beside him in Rome and Constantinople. That I would be his partner. And now Rome grows dangerous, and the partner is sent to wait on a ship while her husband walks into the fire alone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Her jaw tightens. For a moment, the Lucia who warned you she would argue, who promised to drive your advisors to distraction, is fully present. But then her hand moves to her belly again. The gesture is unconscious, protective. And something in her face shifts—the sharp edge giving way to something more complicated.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Catalina cannot be here if there is violence. That much is certain. And I...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She trails off, looking down at where her hand rests. When she looks up again, her eyes are bright with something that might be frustration, might be fear, might be both.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I hate this. I hate that you are right. I hate that I cannot stand beside you tomorrow because I carry the future of your dynasty in my body and that makes me a liability instead of an ally.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches for your hand again, gripping hard.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Promise me something.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can come if you want to Lucia. I will not stop you, but I think it may be better for you to be safe with Catalina.

encounters.recap: In their bedchamber at dawn, Juan reveals to his pregnant wife Lucia the full scope of his nocturnal negotiations with Pope Eugenius—the planned Church reforms, the scholar Parentucelli's role, and the dangerous implications. Lucia grasps the political peril and argues against being sent to safety on the ships, torn between her desire to stand as Juan's partner and her duty to protect their unborn child.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I hate this. I hate that you are right. I hate that I cannot stand beside you tomorrow because I carry the future of your dynasty in my body and that makes me a liability instead of an ally. Promise me something.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can come if you want to Lucia. I will not stop you, but I think it may be better for you to be safe with Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You will not stop me. But you think it would be better. This is how it begins, you know. The slow retreat into the women's quarters. First it is better that I wait on the ship. Then it is better that I remain in Toledo while you ride to war. Then it is better that I manage the household while the men discuss politics. My aunt in Ferrara. Eleven years. That is how it started for her, too. One reasonable decision at a time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She pushes herself up, swinging her legs over the side of the bed. For a moment she sits with her back to you, shoulders tight.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: But I am not a fool. If something goes wrong today—if there is blood in the streets—I cannot run. I cannot fight. I can only be captured and used against you, or...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She does not finish the sentence. When she turns back, her face has composed itself into something harder. The Ferrarese noblewoman who survived two decades of Italian court politics.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will go to the ships. I will take Catalina and my ladies and I will wait like a good wife while you reshape the Church. But you will finish what you started with that promise, Juan. The one I asked for before you interrupted me. Promise me that when this is done—when the Camera is secured and Parentucelli has his commission and the cardinals have learned to swallow their fury—you will come back to me. Not to a ship, not to Naples. To me. Alive and whole. Promise me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I'll come back, I promise. I must write some orders to the men.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia watches as you rise from the bed, her expression unreadable. The promise hangs in the air between you—accepted, but not forgotten.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Today. It is today. You have perhaps three hours until the sun is properly up. You have 591 knights at Ostia. Ten ships. How many do you need for the Camera? Parentucelli cannot secure a building with clerks and good intentions. And the rest? Do they attend the Mass armed? That will send a message, but perhaps not the one you want. Five hundred armored Castilians in St. Peter's looks less like piety and more like conquest.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will need time to prepare Catalina and the ladies. Two hours at minimum, more if you want us gone before the announcement. When do you want the ships ready to sail? And who commands them if... Who commands them, Juan?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have a son Fernando. If I die today, you will be queen-regent until he comes of age. But I will not die today. Write a command to all my knights. I want them in white tabards to attend mass today and me at St Peter's at midday. They are to bring one weapon with them. No crossbows, just one sword, mace or axe per person. They will attend mass and will further instructions from me later. Make sure they get a good breakfast. Get your ladies and Catalina ready to get to the ships soon Lucia. Take my personal guard with you for now, you will be safe and I will be with my knights.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's expression tightens almost imperceptibly at the mention of Fernando. Your son by Isabel. The heir. A reminder of the hierarchy she occupies—wife, but not mother of the succession.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: White tabards. Mass at midday. One weapon each. Breakfast first. And the men for Parentucelli? The Camera building? You said fifty to one hundred could secure it. That needs to be a separate order, does it not? Different instructions, different timing. Parentucelli takes the Camera before the announcement, not during. Unless you want the corrupt officials to have warning while five hundred knights are visibly assembling for Mass.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When the orders are complete and sealed, Lucia rises. The sky outside has shifted from grey to pale gold. Rome is waking.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will have the household ready within two hours. Catalina will be... difficult. She does not like the ship when it is not moving. But I will manage her.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves toward the door, then pauses. Turns back. For a moment, the mask slips. She crosses to where you sit on the edge of the bed, exhaustion finally pulling at your limbs. She takes your face in her hands—her fingers cool against your skin—and kisses you. Not gently. Fiercely.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sleep. You cannot reshape the Church if you collapse during Mass.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I get some sleep and then get back to the vatican and set everything in motion. I ask the pope if he has a handful of men ready to give to Tommaso to secure the camera.

encounters.recap: Lucia reluctantly agrees to withdraw to safety at the ships with Catalina while Juan prepares his knights for the papal reform. Despite her strategic mind and desire to participate, she recognizes the political reality of her pregnancy making her a liability. Juan promises to return alive and issues orders for his knights to attend Mass in white tabards with limited weapons, while planning separate orders for securing the Camera Apostolica.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sleep is shallow and dreamless—the exhausted rest of a body that has pushed too far. You wake to find the sun well up, golden light streaming through the shutters. Someone has left bread, cheese, and watered wine on the table. Lucia is gone. So is Catalina. A servant informs you that the Queen departed for Ostia two hours ago with her household and your personal guard.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Vatican — Late Morning, March 23, 1434. The walk through Vatican corridors feels different in daylight. Servants and minor clergy move about their business, unaware that their world is about to crack open. You catch glances—curious, wary, speculative. Word has spread that the King of Castile spent the night with the Pope. Rome is whispering.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A papal servant leads you to the same private chamber where you drafted documents by candlelight mere hours ago. The table has been cleared. Fresh candles burn. The documents themselves are nowhere to be seen. Pope Eugenius IV stands at the window, gazing out at Rome. He wears his papal vestments now—the white cassock, the red shoes, the simple white zucchetto on his head. Ready for public appearance. Tommaso Parentucelli sits in a corner, looking as though he has not slept at all. His eyes are red-rimmed but alert, and he clutches a leather satchel against his chest. The documents, you realize. He has not let them out of his sight.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your knights?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Assembling for Mass. They will be at St. Peter's by midday.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Captain Pallavicini commands two hundred Vatican guards. We have... spoken with him this morning. He is loyal. He says. We have selected twenty of his men—those Pallavicini vouches for personally. They await your Master Parentucelli's command. Twenty men to secure a building full of clerks who have stolen from the Church for decades. It will have to be enough until your knights can reinforce them.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Twenty is sufficient to hold the doors and prevent document destruction. If we move before anyone knows to resist.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The cardinals are being summoned for the Mass. They believe it is... routine. A celebration of Lent. Colonna. Orsini. Rochetaillée. They will all be there. Watching. You spoke of a sequence last night. The Camera first. Then the announcement. We are ready, Your Majesty. As ready as we shall ever be. Tell us when.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We secure the camera, then go immediately to mass and deliver the announcements. My knights stand ready to reinforce the camera or the papal palace should this be needed.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to the Vatican after a brief rest to finalize the Camera operation. Pope Eugenius has assembled twenty trusted guards under Captain Pallavicini to secure the Camera offices. With Tommaso holding the reform documents and cardinals unknowingly gathering for Mass, they prepare to execute their plan: first secure the Camera, then publicly announce the reforms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Giacomo Pallavicini enters and drops to one knee in a single fluid motion. He is perhaps fifty, with the weathered face of a soldier and close-cropped grey hair. His eyes are dark, watchful—they sweep the room in an instant, cataloguing: the Pope, the King of Castile, the scholar with the satchel. An unusual gathering.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo_pallavicini
exchanges.text: Your Holiness summoned me.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rise, Captain. You have served Us faithfully these three years. You have asked no questions when We required... discretion. Today We ask more than discretion. Today We ask you to choose.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: This man carries documents that will reform the Apostolic Camera. Root and branch. Every corrupt arrangement, every stolen florin, every deal made in shadow—ended. Today. Within the hour. Your twenty men will secure the Camera building. You will prevent any official from leaving, any document from being destroyed, any coin from being moved.

exchanges.speaker: giacomo_pallavicini
exchanges.text: The Camera. Cardinal Condulmer's office. Holiness. The men who work in the Camera have friends. Patrons. Cardinals who have grown comfortable with how business is conducted. If I secure that building, I make enemies of powerful men. Men who will remember my face long after today. What protection do I have?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Captain, today will test all of us. We are here because we will reform the church. And I have pledged myself and my knights to protect those who carry out this important task. Know that we are fighting the good fight, are on the side of justice and that I and my knights are at your disposal. Today and tomorrow. The men you see before you will be the main target of those who will be exposed. I only ask, we only ask you play your part as well.

roll.outcome: Professional Obedience. Pallavicini nods slowly. He will do his duty—but this is a soldier following orders, not a man who believes. He will secure the Camera competently, but do not expect him to take initiative or risks beyond what is strictly commanded.

encounters.recap: Captain Pallavicini is brought into confidence about the Camera operation. Despite Juan's appeal to justice and honor, and promises of protection, Pallavicini responds with professional compliance rather than genuine commitment—he will follow orders but remains calculating about the long-term consequences of opposing powerful Roman families.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallavicini listens. His face remains impassive throughout—the mask of a man who has survived decades in Roman service by revealing nothing. When you finish, there is a pause. His eyes move from you to the Pope to Parentucelli, then back to you.

exchanges.speaker: pallavicini
exchanges.text: I understand, Your Majesty. Your Holiness. You require the Camera building secured. No one leaves, no documents destroyed, no coin moved. Master Parentucelli directs the operation. Castilian knights in reserve. My twenty men and I will hold the building until relieved or given further instructions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns to Parentucelli. The question is practical. Competent. There is nothing wrong with it. And yet. You catch Eugenius's eye. The Pope has noticed it too—the absence of something. Pallavicini will do his duty. He will secure the building, hold the doors, follow every instruction to the letter. But there is no fire in him. No conviction. He is a professional performing a task, not a man joining a cause.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The front entrance. We do this openly—papal authority, not skulking through back passages. They must understand from the first moment that this is sanctioned from above.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk from the papal chambers to the Camera building takes less than five minutes. The Camera building is unassuming. A solid Roman structure of weathered stone, unremarkable except for the papal keys carved above the doorway. Two clerks in black robes stand at the entrance, reviewing documents in the morning light. They look up at the approaching guards with mild curiosity—then see the Pope, and their faces go pale.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Stand aside. By Our apostolic authority, this building is now under special administration.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Inside, chaos gives way to control with surprising speed. Parentucelli transforms. The trembling scholar vanishes; in his place stands a man who has memorized every corridor, every office, every hiding place in this building over twenty years of watching.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: By order of His Holiness, all officials of the Apostolic Camera are to remain in place. You will surrender any keys in your possession. You will touch no documents. You will answer questions truthfully when asked.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Camerlengo has been informed. The keys, if you please.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: While Pallavicini's men hold positions throughout the building, Parentucelli moves to the central records chamber. The room is lined with ledgers. Hundreds of them. Decades of Church finances, bound in leather, stacked on shelves reaching to the ceiling. Parentucelli sets down his satchel and pulls a ledger from the nearest shelf.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Here. This is the servitia communia—the fees for episcopal appointments. Standard rate: one-third of the first year's revenue. But look. This diocese paid twelve hundred florins. The recorded amount is eight hundred. This one—nine hundred paid, six hundred recorded. The difference—four hundred florins here, three hundred there—it goes... There. 'Administrative expenses.' A category that did not exist fifteen years ago.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Holiness. In the past hour, examining only these three ledgers, I can identify at least two thousand florins in... irregularities. And these are merely the most obvious. The careful theft—the arrangements that require cross-referencing with banking records—that will take weeks to unravel. But I have specifics now. Names. Amounts. Dates. When you make your announcement, we do not merely accuse. We demonstrate.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Twenty years, Master Parentucelli. They have been stealing from Us—from the Church—for twenty years. And We never looked.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: You were not meant to look, Holiness. That was the system's purpose.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Then let us end it. The Camera is secured. The evidence is better than We dared hope. Your knights await at St. Peter's? It is time, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Parentucelli, proceed. You have the authority, also to conscript scribes into your service. You cannot do all the accounting on your own. Find men you can trust. We will speak later. How much is in the treasury?

roll.outcome: Better Than Expected. Clean success, and Parentucelli immediately identifies irregularities—ledgers that don't match, coin counts that are wrong. He can already see the shape of the corruption with specific evidence of stolen funds.

encounters.recap: The seizure of the Apostolic Camera proceeds flawlessly under Captain Pallavicini's guards and Parentucelli's direction. All officials comply, keys are surrendered, and no documents are destroyed. Most importantly, Parentucelli immediately discovers concrete evidence of corruption in the ledgers—at least 2,000 florins in documented irregularities with names, amounts, and dates, providing specific proof rather than mere accusations for the coming reform announcement.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Camera is secured. The evidence is better than We dared hope. Your knights await at St. Peter's?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Through the window, you can see the dome of the basilica rising against the Roman sky. Bells will ring soon, calling the faithful—and the cardinals—to Mass.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It is time, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli descends to the vault with two of Pallavicini's guards and both keys. You and Eugenius wait in the records chamber above, surrounded by ledgers that tell their own damning stories. Minutes pass. You hear the heavy clunk of iron locks turning, the groan of hinges that guard the Church's wealth. Then footsteps on the stairs. Parentucelli emerges, his face carefully composed—but you have learned to read him in these past hours. The slight tightness around his eyes. The way his hands grip a small ledger he has brought up from below.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Well?

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The vault contains approximately two hundred and forty-three thousand florins in coin and bullion. There are also promissory notes from the Medici bank totaling eighteen thousand florins—though I would not count those as liquid until we verify the arrangements.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty deposited three hundred and fifteen thousand florins, with explicit designation for crusading purposes, in June of last year.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The ledger shows... Debt service to the Medici: fourteen thousand florins. 'Emergency repairs' to the Lateran Palace: eight thousand. Diplomatic missions to Basel and the Emperor: eleven thousand. Cardinals' subsidies drawn against future revenues: nineteen thousand. 'Administrative expenses'—a category that encompasses everything and specifies nothing: twelve thousand.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: None of it is theft in the legal sense. Every withdrawal has a signature, a justification, a veneer of legitimacy. The system consumed what it always consumes. It simply had more to consume.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Seventy thousand florins. In ten months.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The structural deficit, Holiness. It does not sleep. It does not pause because funds are earmarked for holy purposes. This is why reform is necessary. Not because evil men stole—though some did—but because the institution itself devours faster than it receives.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Two hundred and forty-three thousand florins, Your Majesty. It is not what you entrusted to the Church. But it is enough—barely—to fund the Constantinople expedition and maintain reformed Camera operations while new revenue structures take hold.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: I am sorry. You deserved better stewardship of your sacrifice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bells of St. Peter's begin to toll in the distance. The cardinals will be gathering now, expecting routine, receiving revolution.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Two hundred and forty-three thousand florins. And the truth, finally, of where the rest went. That may prove more valuable than the coin.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Come. We have a Church to reform.

roll.outcome: Expected Losses. 243,000 florins remain of 315,000 deposited. 70,000+ florins consumed by structural deficit and administrative expenses over 10 months.

encounters.recap: The papal treasury assessment reveals that 243,000 florins remain of the 315,000 Juan deposited for crusading purposes ten months prior. The 70,000+ florins lost were consumed not by outright theft but by the Church's structural deficit—debt service, repairs, diplomatic missions, and administrative expenses that devoured the funds through institutional predation rather than criminal intent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bells of St. Peter's begin to toll in the distance. The cardinals will be gathering now, expecting routine, receiving revolution.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Two hundred and forty-three thousand florins. And the truth, finally, of where the rest went. That may prove more valuable than the coin.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Come. We have a Church to reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk from the Camera to St. Peter's takes you through corridors and courtyards that grow increasingly populated. Servants press against walls. Minor clergy bow as the Pope passes. Word is spreading—something is happening—though no one yet knows what.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The cardinals. Fourteen are in Rome. All have been summoned. Most will attend—curiosity if nothing else. They know something is afoot. Your knights assembling at St. Peter's will have confirmed it.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Cardinal Colonna sent word he is unwell. Cardinal Orsini claims pressing business. Whether they appear remains to be seen. Their absence may speak as loudly as their presence.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You will sit in the place of honor, at Our right hand. Your knights will fill the nave. When Mass concludes, We shall address the congregation.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We will announce the reforms. Sign the documents publicly—the Basel decrees, the Camera bull, Parentucelli's commission. All of it, before witnesses. Then We shall call upon you. You offered to repeat your pledge publicly—your protection of the reform and those who carry it out.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Do you still wish to make that pledge, Your Majesty? Before the cardinals, before Rome, before God? Once spoken in St. Peter's, it cannot be unsaid. You bind yourself—and Castile—to whatever follows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before God and men. I will.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great bronze doors of St. Peter's stand open, and the sight within stops your breath for half a heartbeat. Five hundred and ninety-one knights in white tabards fill the nave. They stand in ordered ranks, shoulder to shoulder, the red crosses of the crusade blazing against the white cloth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: As you enter behind the Pope, a ripple passes through your knights. Hands move to sword hilts—not threat, but salute. Five hundred fists press against five hundred hearts. The sound of it echoes off ancient stone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cardinals occupy the choir, arranged in their scarlet ranks like a wound against the marble. You count quickly as you take your seat at Eugenius's right hand. Eleven. Perhaps twelve. Cardinal Capranica catches your eye—a fractional nod. Cardinal Jean de Rochetaillée watches you with unconcealed suspicion, his thin face sharp as a blade.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The liturgy unfolds in its ancient rhythms—the Introibo ad altare Dei, the Kyrie, the Gloria. Latin fills the basilica, rising to the vaulted ceiling and falling back like benediction. Your knights kneel when the congregation kneels, rise when it rises, their movements a half-beat behind the Roman clergy but earnest in their devotion.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Before We continue the sacred liturgy, there is a matter of grave importance that We must address. A matter concerning the governance of Holy Mother Church herself.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We call forward Our faithful servant, Tommaso Parentucelli, to attend Us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A side door opens. Parentucelli enters, still clutching his leather satchel, and walks the length of the nave to kneel before the papal throne. The silence is absolute.

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius leads Juan to St. Peter's Basilica where 591 knights fill the nave for a Mass that will announce sweeping Church reforms. After the liturgy begins, the Pope interrupts to address Church governance and calls Parentucelli forward, setting the stage for public declaration of the reforms and Juan's oath of protection.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Before We continue the sacred liturgy, there is a matter of grave importance that We must address. A matter concerning the governance of Holy Mother Church herself.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We call forward Our faithful servant, Tommaso Parentucelli, to attend Us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A side door opens. Parentucelli enters, still clutching his leather satchel, and walks the length of the nave to kneel before the papal throne. The silence is absolute.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Fratres carissimi... For three years, We have sat upon the throne of Peter. For three years, We have watched. We have waited. We have survived. We told Ourselves that survival was enough. That holding the Church together through crisis was sufficient labor for one pontificate. That the corruption We saw—that the corruption We allowed... was the price of unity. We were wrong. We have been cowards.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The light shifts. The high windows of St. Peter's catch the midday sun at precisely the right angle, and golden radiance pours down upon the papal throne like a river of fire. Eugenius stands haloed in light, his white vestments blazing, and the effect is so sudden and so complete that several knights drop to their knees unbidden.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Today, that ends. Today, We reach out Our hand. The shepherd does not ask which sheep first saw the wolf—he acts to protect the flock.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Fourteen thousand florins in debt service that should have been twelve. Nineteen thousand in cardinal subsidies drawn against revenues that had not yet arrived. Twelve thousand in 'administrative expenses' that correspond to no documented expenditure. This is not evil. This is sickness. A system that rewards corruption and punishes honesty. Today, the system changes.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_albergati
exchanges.text: Your Holiness. I have prayed for this day for forty years. Forty years I have watched and grieved and wondered if God had abandoned His Church. Forty years... Whatever you require of me, Holiness. Whatever service these old bones can render. I am yours.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_capranica
exchanges.text: Your Holiness. The Church has needed this for a generation. Command us.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not command. We invite. The Church is not rebuilt by decree alone—she is rebuilt by faithful hearts working together. Today, We sign these documents. Today, reform begins. But the labor of years lies ahead.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope signs. His hand does not tremble. Parentucelli signs as witness. Cardinal Albergati, still kneeling, is helped to his feet and signs. Cardinal Capranica signs. The scratching of quills on parchment is the only sound.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: There remains one matter. The King of Castile has pledged himself to the protection of this reform and all who labor in its service. He has offered to make this pledge publicly, before God and man, binding himself and his kingdom to the defense of Holy Mother Church in her hour of renewal. Your Majesty. The Church calls upon you. Will you come forward?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: All men must do their best. Do what is right. Act within their means to make the world better. It is within my means to ally my kingdom to the pope as he so bravely reforms our lord's church. Kings have always sought to control or influence the papacy, I offer service without expectation of recompense or gift or favor. The pope is the master of spiritual matters, I pledge myself in his defence so worldly matters can not influence him in the execution of his task. I do so swear before God and men.

roll.outcome: Providence. The hand of God moves visibly in St. Peter's. As Eugenius speaks, miraculous light illuminates the papal throne. Eight cardinals publicly pledge support, documents are signed in solemn ceremony, and the King swears his oath before an awestruck congregation.

encounters.recap: In a moment of divine providence, Pope Eugenius announces sweeping Church reforms in St. Peter's Basilica. Bathed in miraculous light, he confesses past failures and presents comprehensive reforms. Eight cardinals publicly pledge support, reform documents are signed, and King Juan II swears a sacred oath to defend the reformed Church without seeking recompense.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The Church calls upon you. Will you come forward?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Every eye turns to you. Five hundred and ninety-one knights. Eleven cardinals—eight kneeling, three watching. Scores of clergy, witnesses, servants. Tommaso Parentucelli with tears on his cheeks. Pope Eugenius IV, haloed in fading golden light, his hand outstretched. The moment you have worked toward for four years. The oath that cannot be unsaid.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: All men must do their best. Do what is right. Act within their means to make the world better. It is within my means to ally my kingdom to the pope as he so bravely reforms our lord's church. Kings have always sought to control or influence the papacy, I offer service without expectation of recompense or gift or favor. The pope is the master of spiritual matters, I pledge myself in his defence so worldly matters can not influence him in the execution of his task. I do so swear before God and men.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words ring through the basilica, echoing off stone that has heard the prayers of pilgrims for a thousand years. For a moment, nothing moves. Then Cardinal Albergati—still standing where he rose from his knees—crosses himself. His lips move in silent prayer, and fresh tears spill down his ancient face.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_albergati
exchanges.text: Deo gratias. Deo gratias.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The phrase spreads like fire through dry grass. 'Deo gratias.' From the kneeling cardinals. 'Deo gratias.' From the clergy in the congregation. 'DEO GRATIAS.' From five hundred and ninety-one knights, the words erupting as a roar that shakes the very air. Fists strike chests. Swords clear scabbards and rise in salute—not threat, but acclamation.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Benedictus qui venit in nomine Domini.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Three days ago, We did not know if We would live to see Easter. We did not know if the Church We loved could be saved. We did not know if any Christian prince in all the world would stand beside Us rather than seek to use Us. Now We know.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Let all present witness: Juan II of Castile has sworn himself to the defense of Holy Mother Church. Not for land. Not for gold. Not for titles or favors or the advancement of his house. He has sworn for faith. For the belief that the Church can be what Christ intended her to be. This oath is received. This oath is blessed. This oath is sealed before God and all the saints. Let any man who moves against the reform of the Church know that he moves against the Crown of Castile. Let any hand raised against the servants of renewal know that it will be met by Castilian steel. And let all faithful Christians know that the Church is not alone. That she has defenders. That the darkness which has gathered around her will be driven back.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Cardinal Capranica rises from his knees and begins to applaud. The sound is jarring—applause in a church, during Mass—but others take it up. Cardinals. Clergy. And then the knights, who do not clap but stamp their feet and clash their swords against their scabbards until the rhythm becomes thunder. Through it all, Rochetaillée remains seated. His face is unreadable. His two French allies exchange glances. They do not applaud, do not stamp, do not participate. But they do not protest either.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not know what We did to deserve you, Your Majesty. But We thank God for it.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It is done. The documents are signed. The oath is sworn. The Camera is secured. Now we discover what Rome makes of it. What would you have Us do now, Your Majesty? The cardinals will wish to speak with Us—to understand, to negotiate, to position themselves. Parentucelli awaits further instructions. And somewhere beyond these walls, Colonna and Orsini are learning what has transpired in their absence.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What does the holy father require of me? I doubt you want me present with the discussions between you and the cardinals. I will stay nearby with my knights and be ready should anything happen that requires our intervention. Tommaso, I will attach five men to your person with your permission. They can fetch more aid should you in the camera require it.

encounters.recap: In the climactic moment of his Roman mission, Juan II kneels before Pope Eugenius IV in St. Peter's Basilica and swears a sacred oath to defend the Church's reform without expectation of reward. The oath electrifies the assembled crowd of knights, cardinals, and clergy, who respond with thunderous acclamation. The Pope formally blesses the oath and declares that the Church now has a true defender, while French cardinals observe silently, calculating their response.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: What would you have Us do now, Your Majesty? The cardinals will wish to speak with Us—to understand, to negotiate, to position themselves. Parentucelli awaits further instructions. And somewhere beyond these walls, Colonna and Orsini are learning what has transpired in their absence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The question hangs in the air. The oath is sworn. The reform has begun. What comes next?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What does the holy father require of me? I doubt you want me present with the discussions between you and the cardinals. I will stay nearby with my knights and be ready should anything happen that requires our intervention. Tommaso, I will attach five men to your person with your permission. They can fetch more aid should you in the camera require it. Do you want me to do anything else for the moment?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius considers for a moment. The golden light has fully faded now, leaving only the ordinary illumination of candles and high windows. The Pope looks tired—deeply tired—but there is a steadiness in him that was not there yesterday.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Stay nearby, yes. The Palazzo di San Marco, perhaps, or... Your Queen. Your daughter. They sailed for Naples?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ostia first, then Naples if needed.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Good. Good. We would not have them in danger. But We confess We would rest easier knowing you remained in Rome for... a time. Days, at least. Until We see how the cardinals settle.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances toward the scarlet ranks, where knots of conversation have begun to form. Cardinals murmuring to each other. Alliances forming, reforming, shattering.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The discussions with the cardinals—you are right, your presence would complicate them. They must see this as Our reform, not a Spanish imposition. But knowing you are close... That knowledge will concentrate minds wonderfully.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Five men, Your Majesty. Yes. Gratefully accepted. The Camera building is secure, but the work there will take weeks. Months. I will need to interview every official, examine every ledger, trace every arrangement back to its source.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He hesitates. His eyes move to Eugenius, then back to you.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: There is one thing. The letters. To the Christian monarchs—Castile, Aragón, Portugal, Naples, the Empire. His Holiness spoke of sending correspondence, informing them of the reforms, seeking their support. They should go soon. Before... before other versions of today's events reach those courts.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rochetaillée will have a messenger riding for Basel within the hour. The French faction will frame this as they wish—Spanish domination, papal capitulation, whatever serves their purposes. Would you assist with the letters, Your Majesty? Not write them—that must be Our hand, Our seal—but... advise? You know these monarchs. Alfonso of Aragón is your brother by marriage. João of Portugal your father-in-law. Your counsel on how to present this news would be valuable.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: And your signature alongside His Holiness's, on the letter to Castile at least, would carry weight. Let your own kingdom hear of this from their king, not from Roman rumors.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the nave, your knights have begun to organize themselves—some filing out into the Roman sunshine, others clustering near the doors in informal guard positions. Marco Tornesi catches your eye and raises an eyebrow. Orders? The cardinals are moving too. Several approach Eugenius—Capranica first, with Albergati leaning on a younger priest's arm close behind. The French contingent withdraws toward a side chapel, heads bent together. The day is far from over.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will draft the letters after the pope has had a chance to speak with the cardinals. Then we take action accordingly. I will have men stand ready to deliver messages to wherever we want.

encounters.recap: Following the papal reform oath ceremony, Juan arranges security details and discusses strategy with Pope Eugenius and Parentucelli. They plan to draft letters to European monarchs explaining the reforms, while Juan positions his forces to support the Pope during upcoming cardinal negotiations.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: And your signature alongside His Holiness's, on the letter to Castile at least, would carry weight. Let your own kingdom hear of this from their king, not from Roman rumors.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the nave, your knights have begun to organize themselves—some filing out into the Roman sunshine, others clustering near the doors in informal guard positions. Marco Tornesi catches your eye and raises an eyebrow. Orders? The cardinals are moving too. Several approach Eugenius—Capranica first, with Albergati leaning on a younger priest's arm close behind. The French contingent withdraws toward a side chapel, heads bent together. The day is far from over.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will draft the letters after the pope has had a chance to speak with the cardinals. Then we take action accordingly. I will have men stand ready to deliver messages to wherever we want.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Wise. Let Us see what shape the College takes before We commit words to parchment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns as Cardinal Capranica approaches, the diplomat's face carefully composed. Behind him, Albergati totters forward, still supported by a young priest, his ancient eyes bright with fervor.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_capranica
exchanges.text: Your Holiness, the College would benefit from... clarification. On several matters.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We expected as much. We shall retire to the consistory chamber. All cardinals present are invited to attend.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances back at you one final time.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We will send word when We have news, Your Majesty. Pray for Us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then he is gone, scarlet-robed figures clustering around him as he moves toward the side chambers. Parentucelli bows to you and hurries after—he will be needed to answer questions about the Camera's state. You find Marco Tornesi at the nave's entrance.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: Majestad. The men are asking what happens now. Some are half-convinced they just witnessed a miracle.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: Did we?

encounters.recap: Following the dramatic reform announcement, Juan decides to wait for the papal consistory results before drafting official letters. The Pope meets with the College of Cardinals for clarification while Juan prepares his forces to deliver messages across Christendom based on the outcome of the cardinal negotiations.

roll.outcome: Flight to safety. Colonna quietly departs Rome within hours, traveling to Colonna family strongholds in the Campagna. He sends measured letters—not denouncing the Pope, but expressing 'concerns' and 'need for reflection.' He positions himself outside Rome but not openly opposed. Safe, but absent from the political arena where decisions will be made. His Roman influence bleeds away daily.

encounters.recap: Cardinal Prospero Colonna, facing the papal reforms that threaten his corrupt arrangements, chooses flight over confrontation. He quietly retreats to Colonna family strongholds, maintaining plausible deniability while removing himself from the immediate political arena in Rome.

roll.outcome: Valuable cooperation. Orsini decides that with Colonna gone, the path to influence runs through the reformers. He provides Eugenius with useful intelligence: which Camera officials are most compromised, where hidden documents might be found, which cardinals are quietly coordinating opposition. He is betraying his class to preserve his position. Self-interested, but genuinely helpful.

encounters.recap: Following Cardinal Colonna's flight from Rome, Cardinal Orsini calculates that cooperation with the papal reforms offers the best path to maintaining influence. He provides valuable intelligence to Pope Eugenius about corrupt Camera officials, hidden documents, and opposition cardinals, effectively betraying his aristocratic allies to secure his position in the new order.

roll.outcome: Genuine conversion. The impossible: a French faction leader recognizing that the cause he served was more about power than reform. Rochetaillée sends word to Basel that the Council's work is vindicated—Rome has adopted their reforms. He recommends declaring victory and ending the constitutional conflict. Simultaneously, he approaches Eugenius offering to serve as bridge between Rome and Basel. The French faction in Rome fractures as their leader changes sides.

encounters.recap: Cardinal Jean de Rochetaillée, leader of the French faction at Rome, experiences an unexpected conversion after witnessing the papal reforms. Despite years of opposing papal authority in favor of conciliar supremacy, he now recognizes that actual reform matters more than constitutional power struggles. He sends word to Basel recommending reconciliation and offers to serve as a bridge between Rome and the Council, causing a fracture within his own faction.

roll.outcome: Valuable partnership. The Medici provide substantial assistance: detailed records of Camera transactions, information about where money actually went, documentation of arrangements that corrupt officials tried to hide. In exchange, they request only that legitimate debts be honored and that the Medici remain the Camera's banking partner. Parentucelli gains weeks of investigative work. The reform is strengthened.

encounters.recap: The Medici Bank's reaction to the Camera reform is determined through a strategic assessment roll. Despite initial concerns about their 60,000 florin debt and loss of leverage over indebted cardinals, the Medici choose valuable partnership, providing Parentucelli with detailed financial records and documentation of corrupt arrangements while requesting only debt recognition and continued banking relationship.

roll.outcome: Flight of the most guilty. Three or four officials with the greatest personal exposure flee Rome before dawn—taking what portable wealth they can carry and documents that would have incriminated them. They scatter to different destinations: one to Florence, one toward Naples, one to family in the countryside. The reform loses potential witnesses, but also loses the most corrupt actors. Those who remain are more likely to cooperate. Some gaps in the records will never be filled.

encounters.recap: As Parentucelli's Camera reform continues, the most compromised officials flee Rome with incriminating documents, while the remaining staff become more cooperative. The investigation loses some evidence but gains a cleaner pool of potential witnesses.

roll.outcome: Bitter private confrontation. Condulmer demands immediate private audience with his uncle. The conversation is painful—accusations of betrayal, family loyalty invoked, tears and anger. Condulmer does not publicly oppose but makes clear he considers himself wronged. The relationship is damaged. Condulmer withdraws from curial affairs, nursing grievance. He becomes a potential rallying point for anyone dissatisfied with the reform—not actively opposing, but visibly wounded.

encounters.recap: Cardinal Francesco Condulmer, the Pope's nephew and nominal head of the Apostolic Camera, reacts to his exclusion from the reform process with a bitter private confrontation with Pope Eugenius IV. The family relationship is damaged as Condulmer withdraws from curial affairs while nursing his grievance, becoming a potential focal point for reform opposition.

roll.outcome: Symbolic without substance. The cardinals maintain their public commitment but provide little practical help. They attend ceremonies, make appropriate statements, express support in general terms. But when Parentucelli needs specific assistance—access to records, pressure on reluctant officials, decisions on difficult cases—the cardinals are unavailable, noncommittal, or defer to others. The reform proceeds on Juan's strength and Parentucelli's determination, not cardinal support.

encounters.recap: The eight reform cardinals who publicly knelt and pledged support prove disappointing in practice. While maintaining their public commitment, they provide only symbolic backing rather than practical assistance to Parentucelli's reform efforts. The transformation must rely primarily on Juan's backing and Parentucelli's own determination rather than sustained cardinal support.

roll.outcome: Growing doubt. The internal problems trouble Pallavicini. Condulmer's grievance, passive cardinals, escaped officials—these are warning signs he recognizes from years of Vatican service. He continues his duty but his heart isn't in it. His men sense his uncertainty. The guards perform adequately but without energy. Small things begin to slip—delayed responses, incomplete reports, opportunities missed.

encounters.recap: Captain Giacomo Pallavicini of the Vatican Guard, observing the reform's progress, becomes increasingly troubled by internal Church problems despite external support. His growing doubts affect his men's performance, creating security vulnerabilities as small operational failures begin to accumulate.

roll.outcome: Passive acceptance. The cardinals accept what they cannot change. Colonna fled; resistance seems futile. They agree to Eugenius's proposals without enthusiasm. They will not obstruct Parentucelli, but they will not assist him either. The meeting concludes with formal agreement and informal disengagement. The reform has the College's acquiescence, not its support. Adequate for proceeding; insufficient for thriving.

encounters.recap: The papal consistory meeting following the extraordinary Mass produces lukewarm results. While the cardinals formally accept the reform proposals, they do so without enthusiasm or commitment. The College offers acquiescence rather than support - adequate for proceeding with implementation but insufficient for the reform to truly thrive. Juan remains available with his knights while Eugenius faces the challenge of governing with a passive College of Cardinals.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Roman sun has begun its descent, casting long shadows across the flagstones where your knights have assembled in loose formation. They've been fed—bread, cheese, and watered wine provided by Vatican servants who eye them with a mixture of fear and fascination. The men are in good spirits, though restless. They've witnessed something extraordinary and now they wait, unsure what comes next.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: The men are asking, Majestad. Do we stay? Do we return to the ships? Some are wondering if there'll be fighting. They're ready if there is.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon stretches. Servants come and go. Occasionally a minor cleric scurries past, carefully not meeting your eyes. The Vatican has the feel of a beehive after someone has struck it—activity, anxiety, purpose, but no one quite sure where the danger lies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: An hour before sunset, a figure emerges from the Vatican and walks directly toward you. Not a servant. Not a guard. A cardinal in scarlet robes, moving with deliberate purpose. Cardinal Jean de Rochetaillée. The French faction leader. The man who remained seated while others knelt. The man who reports to d'Allemand at Basel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He approaches alone, without attendants—unusual for a prince of the Church. His thin face is difficult to read. He stops at a respectful distance and inclines his head.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I wonder if you might spare a moment for conversation.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Bien, mon cardinale. I gladly make time to speak with you.

roll.outcome: Passive acceptance. The cardinals accept what they cannot change. Colonna fled; resistance seems futile. They agree to Eugenius's proposals without enthusiasm. They will not obstruct Parentucelli, but they will not assist him either. The meeting concludes with formal agreement and informal disengagement. The reform has the College's acquiescence, not its support. Adequate for proceeding; insufficient for thriving.

encounters.recap: Juan maintains a vigil with his knights in the Vatican courtyard after the papal reforms. The consistory results in passive acceptance from the College of Cardinals. Cardinal Rochetaillée, the French faction leader, approaches Juan privately for conversation as the day ends.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Rochetaillée's expression flickers—surprise, perhaps, at the French. A small acknowledgment of his origins that could be courtesy or could be calculation. With kings, it is difficult to tell.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances at the knights nearby—close enough to intervene, far enough for private conversation. He makes no move to suggest greater privacy. This will be conducted in the open, it seems. Perhaps that is the point.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I will not waste your time with pleasantries. We both know who I am. We both know what faction I have served these past years at Basel. We both know I did not kneel this morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pauses, letting that sit between you.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: And yet I am here. Speaking with you. Not sending ciphered letters to Cardinal d'Allemand about Spanish tyranny and coerced popes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A thin smile that does not reach his eyes.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: You may wonder why.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns slightly, looking out across the courtyard, toward Rome beyond the Vatican walls.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I have spent eight years fighting for conciliar supremacy. Eight years of procedural warfare, of canonical arguments, of building coalitions against papal excess. I believed—I still believe—that the Church requires accountability, that no man should hold unchecked power, that councils exist for a reason.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back to you.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: And then this morning, I watched a pope weep while confessing his failures. I watched him sign reforms we spent years demanding. I watched a foreign king kneel and swear to defend the Church without asking for a single benefice, a single title, a single florin in return.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes search your face.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I find myself uncertain what to believe, Your Majesty. So I came to ask you directly, because I have learned that secondhand reports are worth less than a moment of honest conversation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He folds his arms.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: What do you actually want? Not the speech you gave in St. Peter's—I heard that. I want to know what Juan of Castile wants from this Church he has sworn to protect.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: God's kingdom on earth! To see my children grow up happy. To live with my fellow men in friendship. To sing the Lord's praises and wonder at his creation every day. And a church as house of the lord fits in that picture perfectly. What better way to live is there? And when I die, I die smiling, knowing that I did what I could. Shall we work together father? To work on building the house of the lord?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Something in Juan's directness—the physical warmth, the absence of agenda, the vision of children and happiness—reaches past Rochetaillée's defenses. He is quiet for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I have spent eight years building walls. Between Rome and Basel. Between factions. Between men who should be brothers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at Juan with something new in his eyes.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Perhaps it is time to build something else.

roll.outcome: The walls crack. Something in Juan's directness reaches past Rochetaillée's defenses. The conversion deepens as he recognizes it is time to build rather than tear down.

encounters.recap: Cardinal Rochetaillée approaches Juan privately to assess his true motivations after not kneeling during the morning ceremony. Juan's simple, heartfelt response about wanting God's kingdom and happy children breaks through the cardinal's political defenses, leading to a genuine offer of collaboration.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cardinal is silent for a long moment. Your hand remains on his shoulder—warm, heavy, the touch of a man rather than a monarch. He does not pull away. His eyes search your face, looking for the seam, the edge, the place where the mask meets the man beneath. He does not find it.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: God's kingdom on earth. Children growing happy. Singing the Lord's praises.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He exhales, and something in his posture shifts. The rigid formality of a Vatican politician gives way to something older, wearier, more human.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I have spent eight years building walls. Between Rome and Basel. Between factions. Between men who should be brothers in Christ. I told myself it was necessary. That the Church needed protection from papal excess. That I was fighting for something sacred. Perhaps I was. Perhaps I still believe that. But somewhere in those eight years, I forgot what the Church exists for. It became about winning. About being right. About ensuring that my vision of governance prevailed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reaches up and removes your hand from his shoulder—not rejection, but deliberation. He holds it for a moment, examining it as though it might contain answers.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: You have five hundred knights in this courtyard. You have a pope who owes you everything. You could demand bishoprics, benefices, a cardinal's hat for your confessor, influence over appointments for a generation. Instead you speak of children and happiness and building the house of the Lord. Either you are the most dangerous man I have ever met, or you are exactly what you appear to be. And I find, to my considerable discomfort, that I am beginning to believe the latter.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Yes, Your Majesty. Let us work together. Let us see what we can build. But understand—I have believed in things before that proved false. I will watch. I will test. And if you prove to be other than you seem... What would you have me do? Specifically. For this house of the Lord we are to build together.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We must all do what we can father. I am no cardinal and you are no king. We both have our battles to fight. What do you think about the reformation decree? Do you agree?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: You ask my honest opinion, Your Majesty? Not what I think you wish to hear? The reform decrees—pluralism, concubinage, annates—these are what Basel has demanded for years. I cannot oppose them without opposing everything I claimed to fight for. The substance is sound. The Camera reform is more complex. The corruption is real. But I have concerns. First: Parentucelli answers only to the Pope. No external accountability. Second: the amnesty. Does forgiveness extend to men whose corruption may cost Christian lives? Third: What happens when you leave, Your Majesty? When you sail for Constantinople—what holds this together?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You must understand that we had to start with just a few men in a room, not knowing if the cardinals who are the actual problem, would support us. We could not think of another way to make sure this reform could take root. And the amnesty only covers the traditional conduct. When Tommaso has taken control and the church has accepted these reforms, he will move against the offenders that have done most harm outside what would be acceptable. If my knights are needed here, I will leave them. I will not just sail away and leave the pope to his fate. These reforms must succeed. So far, it all seems to be going smoothly. How did the meeting with the pope go? How are the other cardinals?

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: You admit to improvisation. To uncertainty. To not knowing if it would work. I have spent eight years in councils where men would rather die than admit they did not have a plan. You would leave your knights in Rome. You would sail to Constantinople—to face the Ottoman Sultan with diminished forces—so that the Pope retains his protection. Either you are mad, or you truly believe what you said about God's kingdom on earth.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: His Holiness emerged with formal agreement. The cardinals will not obstruct. But there was no fire in that room, Your Majesty. No conviction. They accept because Colonna fled and resistance seems futile. Cardinal Condulmer—the Pope's nephew—demanded private audience with His Holiness. The conversation was not quiet. He has withdrawn from curial affairs. He feels himself wronged. Men who feel betrayed by family sometimes do foolish things. You asked how you can help. Perhaps the question is: how do we fill that hollow center before you sail east?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We shall have to find allies the coming days. But we start with just ourselves. Where there was just one this morning, now there are two. We continue. I will always make time for you sir cardinal. Is there anything else?

roll.outcome: The walls crack. Something in Juan's directness reaches past Rochetaillée's defenses. He commits to partnership while maintaining principled scrutiny.

encounters.recap: Cardinal Rochetaillée undergoes a spiritual transformation during his conversation with Juan in the Vatican courtyard. Initially defensive, he gradually opens up about his eight years of institutional fighting and his lost sense of purpose. Juan's genuine faith and offer to leave knights in Rome to protect the reforms convinces Rochetaillée to become an ally. The cardinal provides intelligence about the consistory's passive resistance and warns about Pope Eugenius's wounded nephew, Cardinal Condulmer, as a potential threat to the reforms.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: A wounded nephew is a small thing. Until it is not. Men who feel betrayed by family sometimes do foolish things. And men who wish the reform to fail now have a sympathetic figure—a cardinal wronged by his own uncle for the sake of Spanish influence.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: This is the ground on which your reform stands, Your Majesty. External support—myself, Orsini, even the Medici, I hear—but hollow within. The Pope has acquiescence, not allies. Parentucelli has authority, but the men who should support him offer only words.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: You asked how you can help. Perhaps the question is: how do we fill that hollow center before you sail east?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We shall have to find allies the coming days. But we start with just ourselves. Where there was just one this morning, now there are two. We continue. I will always make time for you sir cardinal. Is there anything else?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Rochetaillée regards you for a long moment. The evening light catches the silver in his hair, the lines around his eyes that speak of years spent in airless chambers debating points of canon law while the world outside continued without him.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Where there was one, now there are two. You make it sound like the Gospel. The mustard seed.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I came here to take your measure, Your Majesty. To determine whether you were a threat to be managed or an opportunity to be exploited. I find instead that I am... unsettled. You do not fit the categories I have spent a lifetime constructing.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I will write to Cardinal d'Allemand tonight. I will recommend that Basel accept these reforms as vindication of conciliar principles. I will urge reconciliation rather than continued conflict. I cannot promise he will listen. D'Allemand has his own ambitions, his own vision. But my voice carries weight, and I will use it.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: One more thing, Your Majesty. A word of counsel, if you will permit it. Cardinal Condulmer. The wounded nephew. Do not leave that wound to fester. His Holiness cannot heal it—he is the one who inflicted it. But you... You are outside the family. You owe Condulmer nothing, and he owes you nothing. Sometimes a word from an outsider reaches where family cannot.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: I do not presume to tell a king his business. But you asked what might fill the hollow center. Sometimes it begins with one man who feels seen rather than discarded.

exchanges.speaker: jean_de_rochetaillee
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I will not forget this conversation. Whatever comes, know that Jean de Rochetaillée heard you speak of God's kingdom and children's happiness, and believed you meant it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns and walks back toward the Vatican, scarlet robes catching the fading light. The courtyard settles into evening quiet. Your knights have found positions against walls and columns, some dicing, others praying, most simply waiting with the patience of men accustomed to long campaigns.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: Majestad. A messenger from the Camera. Parentucelli requests your presence when convenient. He says he has found something you should see.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando? Come to me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A knight is dispatched into the Vatican, and some minutes later, Fray Hernando emerges from the basilica's shadow. He has been at prayer, you suspect—his knees are dusty, his expression carrying that particular stillness that comes from hours spent in conversation with God.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: Majestad. I watched from the colonnade. The French cardinal. He walked differently when he left than when he arrived. You sent for me. How may I serve, my son?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What do you think of what happened here today Fray? You have been with me for so long, this must be an important day for you and the church.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando does not answer immediately. He turns to look at St. Peter's, its dome now painted in shades of rose and gold by the setting sun. His weathered face is difficult to read—contemplation, perhaps, or the careful marshaling of thoughts he knows must be spoken with precision.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: An important day. Yes. Perhaps one of the most important I will witness in my lifetime. I watched a pope confess his failures before God and man. I watched cardinals kneel in what appeared to be genuine repentance. I watched you swear an oath that binds your kingdom to the defense of the Church, asking nothing in return. And I watched light fall upon the papal throne as though heaven itself was watching.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: I should feel triumph. Joy. Vindication. Everything we have worked toward since that chapel in Rome four years ago, when you stripped yourself before Pope Martin and offered everything to God. And I do feel those things. But I also feel... Unease.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: Do you remember what I told you after Florence? After your speech moved the crowd to tears and men threw coins at your feet? I warned you about pride. About the danger of believing your own legend. About the ease with which a man can mistake the crowd's adulation for God's approval.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: Today was not Florence. Today was not performance. I watched you, Juan. I saw your face when you knelt. That was real. That was faith, not theatre. And yet. The light, mijo. The golden light that fell upon Eugenius as he spoke. Half of Rome will say it was a miracle. The hand of God, blessing this reform, confirming that we act in His name.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: Perhaps it was. I am a poor Franciscan friar. I do not presume to know when God chooses to make His presence manifest and when He does not. But I have also seen light fall through windows at opportune moments that signified nothing more than the movement of clouds. I have seen men take coincidence for confirmation and build entire theologies on accidents of weather.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando_de_talavera
